awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: PEEC Phase II: 2+2+2+Infinity: Pipeline for Tribal Preengineering to Society
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. The PEEC-II track provides support for studies or educational research conducted by institutions that have had earlier Pre-Engineering Education Collaborative (PEEC) awards.  The intent of PEEC-II is to capture, analyze, and disseminate the impact of these awards on the participating institutions, faculty, or students, and their communities. PEEC and PEEC-II are partnerships between TCUP and the Directorate for Engineering.

This collaboration among TCUP colleges Sitting Bull College (SBC), Cankdeska Cikana Community College (CCCC), Nueta Hidatsa Sahnish College (NHSC), and Turtle Mountain Community College (TMCC), and North Dakota State University (NDSU), is the culmination of more than 15 years of active engagement in STEM education on North Dakota reservations. It builds on the foundation of their PEEC award which created formal partnerships, implemented student support structures at NDSU, and developed means to support pre-engineering coursework at remote tribal college locations through distance learning and support of tribal college faculty.  The goals of this project are to 1) investigate and document the relationship between a new hybrid distance learning model applied to engineering education and its impact on recruitment, persistence and graduation of American Indian students, and 2) investigate and document the critical elements of the learning and support environments that can improve student success within engineering majors.

Along with creating sustainable and supportive pathways to engineering degrees for American Indian students, the broader impact of this project will come from the value of the distance learning model and its assessment, disseminated broadly, which can support STEM learning at the participating institutions as well as at other institution partnerships that are trying to improve pathways between rural or isolated schools and four-year institutions.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Two goals were set for the Phase II portion (2016-2022) of the PEEC collaborative which are as follows:

1)  To authenticate a correlation between the hybrid distance learning model as applied to the Pre-Engineering Educational Collaborative and resultant student success.

2)  To demonstrate the success of the Phase I learning and support environments in the support of student success during the duration of the grant periods.

A qualitative interpretation of the outcomes of these goals is to recognize that the hybrid distance learning model (HDLM) was utilized as a necessary pre-requisite in order to enable the collaboration to function. In other words, given the situation of the consortium being made up of four rural tribal colleges spread out over a large geographical area with sparse populations and limited faculty resources, the HDLM was the only option to proceed with in order to initiate and maintain a practical learning environment. The HDLM addressed the inherent challenges presented by the collaboration concept as mentioned above. These being the large geographical area the campuses covered, as well as the lack of a complete engineering faculty staff at each institution due to the inherently low enrollment at each school. Overcoming distance with the communications technology implemented and being able to pool the faculty resources of all participating TCU?s as well as the mainstream institution of NDSU were envisioned as solutions which indeed came to fruition in actual practice.

The second goal can be looked at in the same qualitative lens by the fact that many of the successful students produced by the PEEC program would not have been able to navigate the same academic career path had they not been a member of the PEEC student body. Granted some of the persons would have found their niche in engineering on their own accord but many would not have. The support system outside of PEEC for TCU students and prospective TCU students coming from the respective reservations and primary school systems is not conducive to the same objectives being achieved. Hence, the rationale behind the PEEC concept was proven out during incorporation.  

Cankdeska Cikana produced 5 pre-engineering graduates with 2 of these presently holding a bachelor?s degree from NDSU in the Civil and Mechanical disciplines, respectively. The third is in the process of completing a four-year degree at UND in Bio-Engineering. Of these 3, 2 are going on for advanced degrees probably culminating in PhD?s. The 2 CCCC graduates whose terminal degree was the Associate?s at Cankdeska are employed and productive community members.

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2022
Modified by: Cynthia A Lindquist
